creator: jkosin@beta.intcomgrp.com
text:
mod_cgi fails to load with 2.0.55....  I get the following error in my logfiles:

Oct 24 08:24:27 beta httpd: Syntax error on line 237 
of /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf:
Oct 24 08:24:27 beta httpd: Cannot load /etc/httpd/modules/mod_cgi.so into 
server: /etc/httpd/modules/mod_cgi.so: undefined symbol: 
apr_procattr_addrspace_set
Oct 24 08:24:27 beta httpd: httpd startup failed

creator: rpluem@apache.org
text:
I guess the problem is that you are using an outdated apr library. Try to
recompile with at least apr / apr-util 0.9.7. The library bundled with the
sources is 0.9.7 or if you have installed precompiled Fedora rpm packages also
update the apr / apr-util packages.

creator: jkosin@beta.intcomgrp.com
text:
Thanks,
That fixes it; but, why don't you check the installed version of apr?

I'm closing because the problem is fixed for me with 0.9.7 of apr.

James

creator: jorton@redhat.com
text:
This is a real bug, it's totally unnecessary for mod_cgi to depend on 0.9.7, it
could just avoid using the _addrspace stuff if built against older versions with
a simple APR_VERSION_* check.

creator: jkosin@beta.intcomgrp.com
text:
Joe,
That is not the point.  Ruediger pointed out that the httpd source contains 
headers for the apr-0.9.7 sources to compile against.  What your asking is 
doable; but, at a large cost in the long run.  I'd rather update apr than risk 
possible security issues or worse performace issues with httpd.
I'll let the experts decide if this is a real problem.
A dependancy issue is not a BUG that requires this kind of attention, which is 
why I responded and closed the report quickly.
James

creator: jkosin@beta.intcomgrp.com
text:
I'm reclosing this bug, marking it as LATER.

The fix is to update dependancies on the apr and apr-util from
http://apr.apache.org/ to at lease version 0.9.7...

I personally don't see this as a real bug anymore but a dependancy on mod_cgi 
which may need fixing depending on the developers of mod_cgi and their wish for 
backward compatibility with versions < 0.9.7.
There are three fixes as options currently.
  (1)  Comment out the mod_cgi from the httpd.conf file, which fixes the apache 
server running again.
  (2)  Update to the latest apr modules for apache.
  (3)  Wait for a fix (or backport) of a fix to allow apr < 0.9.7.

I don't suggest (3) unless someone is willing to take on the task of making a 
patch that works and is willing to work with the mod_cgi development team on an 
acceptable solution.  Though I'm sure they warned everone when developing for 
2.0.55 of apache this would happen.

Me personally, will have to make more of an effort to read the documentation 
more before reporting these things as bugs.  I am absolutely sure that 
somewhere in the documentation for apache the dependancy on 0.9.7 is stated 
clearly in black and white.

creator: chip@force-elite.com
text:
Please don't close this bug quite yet.  We need to either fix mod_cgi to use
lower versions of APR, or fix our configure script to error out when using APR
<0.9.7.

I'm getting the same (similiar) error while trying to execute a cgi script that
I have in my cgi-bin directory.  The error I'm getting shows:

--- BEGIN ERROR

/usr/sbin/httpd: symbol lookup error: /usr/sbin/httpd: undefined symbol:
apr_procattr_addrspace_set

--- END ERROR

I'm a little confused on the resolution of this problem, because isn't the apr
and apr-util included in the httpd tarball (under the srclib directory)?  Aren't
those utilities built and compiled along with apache at the time of
configuration and make?
creator: MikeDawg@gmail.com

text:
No, they are not compiled or included by apache at make time.  The configure 
script finds the headers needed already installed on your system or should 
error out with a poblem finding the APR headers.

The problem may be with APR itself.  APR-0.9.7 should be compatible with an 
older version back to APR-0.9.0; but, it doesn't appear so in this case; 
because the mod_cgi development is using a new API structure/function and it is 
not present in prior versions.

What really needs to happen is mod_cgi would need to test the APR version at 
run-time and compinsate appropriately or to fail at compile time.
creator: jkosin@beta.intcomgrp.com
jkosin@beta.intcomgrp.com
text: I removed FIXED from the summary, so someone doesn't overlook this problem.

creator: covener@gmail.com
text: worth keeping open if we got to it, but now superceded.
